DGACM.relevance_comment: Requests the Secretary-General, when planning the calendar of conferences and meetings, to avoid simultaneous peak periods and avoid scheduling related bodies too closely together. DGACM (the Department) is responsible for planning and coordinating conference services and the calendar across duty stations (see PPB: overall orientation and subprogramme planning/coordination paragraphs such as 2.33 and the Department’s remit in 2.1). This SG instruction will be implemented operationally by the Department (calendar and meeting planning).

Also requests the Secretary-General to ensure that any modification to the calendar of conferences and meetings is implemented strictly in accordance with the mandate of the Committee on Conferences and other relevant GA resolutions. The Department executes conference scheduling and implements Committee on Conferences guidance (PPB 2.1, subprogramme planning/coordination roles such as 2.33), so this directs work the Department will carry out.

Requests the Secretary-General to report to the General Assembly through the Committee on Conferences on the methodology that accurately reflects the provision of conference services to regional and other major groupings. DGACM prepares and provides such conference-servicing data and methodologies (PPB: subprogramme 2 planning and coordination; reporting of key performance indicators in 2.37–2.38), so this creates a task that the Department is expected to implement or supply input for.

Requests the Secretary-General, when preparing budget proposals for conference services, to ensure that the level of resources proposed for temporary assistance is commensurate with full demand for services. DGACM is responsible for planning and proposing conference-servicing resource needs and for matching temporary assistance to workload (PPB: paragraphs on managing surges, temporary assistance and resource planning, e.g. 2.7, 2.33), so this budgetary instruction falls to the Department to implement.

Requests the Secretary-General to continue to report in writing on the utilization rates of interpretation services and conference facilities at all duty stations. DGACM produces utilization statistics and reporting for interpretation and conference facilities across duty stations (PPB: planning/coordination and reporting functions in subprogramme 2 and programme support, e.g. 2.33, 2.37), so this directs reporting tasks implemented by the Department.

Also requests the Secretary-General to develop methods and indicators for assessing the performance of conference services (cost-effectiveness, efficiency, productivity) and to report thereon. DGACM is mandated in the PPB to develop harmonized KPIs and provide performance data (see 2.33, 2.37 and programme support on evaluation and data analytics 2.226–2.229), so this instruction creates a requirement the Department will operationalize.

Stresses that the Department is responsible for the implementation of policy, formulation of standards and guidelines, overseeing and coordinating United Nations conference services and the overall management of resources under the relevant budget section, while the Offices at Geneva, Vienna and Nairobi remain responsible for day-to-day operational activities. This paragraph explicitly assigns responsibilities to DGACM and is a direct mandate defining the Department’s core functions (matches PPB summary of mandates in 2.1 and the Department’s role throughout the programme).

Reiterates the request to the Secretary-General to ensure that documentation is available in accordance with the six‑week rule for distribution simultaneously in the six official languages. DGACM’s subprogramme 3 (Documentation services) is responsible for producing and issuing parliamentary documentation simultaneously in all official languages (PPB: objectives and planned results in 2.45–2.53), so this is an instruction that DGACM will be required to implement.

Reiterates deep regret concerning failure of author departments to abide by a prior provision and requests the Secretary-General to take corrective measures to ensure full implementation. Ensuring timely submission and processing of documentation falls to DGACM operationally (see PPB: documentation timeliness and quality mandates in 2.45–2.56); thus SG-directed corrective measures will be executed by the Department.

Requests the Secretary-General to take all necessary measures to ensure the compliance of the Secretariat, organizations, bodies and organs with the request contained in paragraph 3 of the section, and to submit a report on violations. Compliance and reporting on documentation and multilingual issuance are functions DGACM carries out (PPB: documentation services and Secretariat-wide multilingual coordination noted in 2.1 and 2.3), so the Department will implement these measures and reporting.

Notes that the Department will assign timing of submission of manuscripts taking into account the programme of work of the session and time needed to produce the document simultaneously in six official languages at high quality. This sentence explicitly directs an operational role to DGACM in scheduling and timing for manuscript submission and multilingual processing (directly aligns with PPB subprogramme 3 responsibilities and the Department’s mandate described in 2.1 and 2.46–2.56).

Notes with concern the delay in issuance of verbatim and summary records and requests the Secretary-General to take appropriate measures to ameliorate the situation. Processing and issuance of verbatim and summary records are core functions of DGACM (PPB subprogramme 4 Meetings and publishing services and subprogramme 3 documentation/verbati mref; see 2.59–2.66 and 2.48–2.56), so SG measures to reduce delays will be implemented by the Department.

Also reiterates the request to the Secretary-General to ensure the communication of resolutions adopted by the General Assembly to Member States within fifteen days of the close of each session. DGACM is responsible for publication and distribution of official documents and records (PPB: publishing and documentation services in subprogrammes 3 and 4, and overall mandate in 2.1), so this is a concrete delivery obligation the Department executes.

Requests the Secretary-General to ensure that efforts continue to be made to improve the quality control of language services at all duty stations. DGACM leads and manages language and documentation services and quality assurance (PPB: translation quality management, training and standards in 2.46–2.53), so SG action here will be carried out through the Department.

Also reiterates the request to the Secretary-General to ensure continuous dialogue between translation staff and interpretation staff among UN HQ and duty stations and between translation divisions and Member States with regard to standardization of terminology. DGACM is the Secretariat-wide coordinator for multilingualism and maintains terminology resources (PPB: role on multilingualism 2.1, Office of the Coordinator for Multilingualism 2.3, and UNTERM reference in 2.46), so this directs coordination work that the Department implements.

Requests the Secretary-General to conduct consultations, with the Member States concerned, on the improvement of the translation services. The Department is responsible for translation/documentation service delivery and for engaging Member States on terminology/quality (PPB: documentation services and outreach in 2.46, 2.54 and UNTERM management), so SG-led consultations will be implemented operationally by DGACM.
